awd_titl_txt: The Roles of Heterogeneity, Mechanics, and the Environment in Biofilm Growth and Emergent Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Biofilms are ubiquitous surface-attached bacterial communities that can cause major problems in industrial settings by fouling surfaces and by clogging pipes and filtration devices. However, biofilms can also be beneficial, for instance, in waste-water treatment and in microbiomes. The project will employ three-dimensional imaging, genetic techniques, mechanical measurements of biofilm properties, and biophysical theory and modeling to provide a unified, multi-scale characterization of biofilms that spans from the level of the cell to that of tightly organized collectives of thousands of cells. The results will define how properties that emerge in the "collective" determine the biofilm's material properties. The project will further provide opportunities for interdisciplinary training within an integrated research framework in which students and postdocs from biology, chemistry, engineering, and physics spend significant time in laboratories other than their own. 

In this research, the three integrated thrusts are:  (1) to explore the origins and consequences of behavioral heterogeneity in growing biofilms, (2) to characterize biofilm mechanics from the micro-scale (a single cell or cluster of cells) to the macro-scale (the biofilm), and (3) to determine how physico/chemical and mechanical features of the environment influence microscopic and macroscopic biofilm properties. The focus is on the model quorum-sensing marine bacterium, Vibrio cholerae. The fundamental understanding gained through this research will enable development of biological and engineering strategies to promote or discourage formation of bacterial biofilms in relevant industrial and other applied settings, and, by connecting micro-scale and environmental features to macroscopic properties, may enable the discovery and design of new materials. Finally, the interdisciplinary work will lead to understanding of spatial and temporal gene expression programs in biofilms at the single-cell level and reveal how those programs, in conjunction with environmental factors, dictate the large-scale architectural and mechanical features of these multicellular systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of our research centers on pioneering concepts and technologies in three-dimensional imaging, mutagenesis, mechanical and rheological measurements, and biophysical theory and modeling to deliver a unified, multiscale characterization of bacterial biofilms that span scales from the level of the individual cell to that of tightly organized collectives of thousands of cells. Bacterial biofilms are communities of cells adhered to surfaces, which occur in many relevant industrial, medical, and ecological settings. A defining feature of a bacterial biofilm is the three-dimensional extracellular polymer matrix that encases the community and protects resident cells from poisons and other perturbations by acting as a mechanical barrier. Indeed, bacterial biofilms are particularly recalcitrant to the penetration of chemicals, such as antimicrobials. Bacterial biofilm formation relies on the cell-to-cell chemical communication process called quorum sensing. Our focus was on the model quorum-sensing and biofilm-forming bacterium Vibrio cholerae and an exploration of how quorum sensing drives biofilm development in space and time. In particular, we developed advanced microscopy techniques that enabled spatiotemporal analyses of gene expression in growing biofilms at single cell resolution. As a companion technology, we developed a computational biofilm segmentation method that integrates mathematical image processing and segmentation algorithms to (i) identify cell positions and gene expression levels at single cell resolution, to (ii) track the evolution of spatial gene expression gradients over time, and to (iii) identify heterogeneous populations of cells. Taken together, our research is revealing how quorum-sensing mechanisms control gene expression patterns in bacterial communities. An applied outcome of our studies could be the development of strategies that enable “on demand” manipulation of normal patterns of gene expression in biofilms possibly for anti-microbial/anti-biofilm interventions.

In addition, we explored how the biofilm environment, e.g., its physical chemistry, can influences biofilm function. We considered methods to disrupt the extracellular polymer matrix by enabling penetration of particles into the biofilm with the goal of increasing the susceptibility of biofilms to antimicrobials. Specifically, we investigated externally imposed chemical gradients as a mechanism to transport polystyrene particles into bacterial biofilms. Using different particles and chemicals, we documented a role for chemical gradients that leads to particle motion into the biofilm and, further, particle reversal out of the biofilm. This response of biofilms to chemical gradients is little recognized and may have implications for the evolution of the biofilm and possibly for eradication.

Taken together, our studies have provided a comprehensive examination of biofilm development, signal transduction, and mechanics from the single-cell to multi-cell levels and in realistic environments that mimic the spatial, temporal, and physical conditions found for bacterial biofilms in nature. We continue to pioneer, develop, and merge tools from molecular biology, optical science, mechanics, physical chemistry, and data rich analyses to advance understanding of bacterial biofilms.

In the area of broader impacts, our work is published in leading peer-reviewed journals in the field and we have trained postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students. Several group members have launched their own independent laboratories in academia or started careers in industry. Outreach to the public is large part of the PIs’ educational activities. Members of our research groups are devoted to lay education. As one example, every year for over 20 years, we have developed a yearly science lecture, that is delivered four times during the December holiday season to ≈1000 children and their parents. Each year the lecture covers a new, different science/engineering topic.
